sociopatterns.imports package¶

Submodules¶

sociopatterns.imports.create_network module¶

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.create_network_from_data(Data, replace_attr=False, label=None)

Create a networkx Graph

Creating a networkx graph from the interaction and the meta data.

Parameters

Data (Data) – Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset.

Returns

  • G (NetworkX Graph) – A graph with a specified degree sequence. Nodes are labeled based on the imported dataset.

  • replace_attr (bool) – If True it will replace string attribute into numeric attributes.

Notes

References

Examples

>>> attr_list = ["ID", "Age", "Sex"]
>>> test_df = Data(path_tij="../../data/Test/tij_test.dat", separator_tij="\\t",
>>>                path_meta="../../data/Test/meta_test.dat", separator_meta="\\t",
>>>                meta_attr_list=attr_list)
>>> test_network = create_network_from_data(test_df)
>>> print(test_network.edges)
[(0, 1), (1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3), (4, 6), (4, 7), (6, 7), (10, 11), (10, 12), (11, 12)]
>>> print(test_network.nodes)
[0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 11, 12]
>>> for i in test_network.nodes:
    >>> print(test_network.nodes[i])
{'Age': 1.0, 'Sex': 1.0}
{'Age': 0.0, 'Sex': 'NaN'}
{'Age': 'NaN', 'Sex': 0.0}
{'Age': 0.0, 'Sex': 1.0}
{'Age': 'NaN', 'Sex': 0.0}
{'Age': 1.0, 'Sex': 1.0}
{'Age': 1.0, 'Sex': 'NaN'}
{'Age': 2.0, 'Sex': 1.0}
{'Age': 2.0, 'Sex': 0.0}
{'Age': 2.0, 'Sex': 1.0}
sociopatterns.imports.create_network.event_time_networks(Data, events)

Create multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames

Creating multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames based on a given event list.

Parameters

  • Data (Data) – Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset.

  • events (list) – A list of tuples that contains the eventname and the start and the beginning of the event.

Returns

  • network_list (list) – A list of all networkx Graphs for a given interval.

  • df_list (list) – A list of all dataframes for a given interval.

Examples

>>> attr_list = ["ID", "Age", "Sex"]
>>> test_df = Data(path_tij="../../data/Test/tij_test.dat", separator_tij="\\t",
>>>       path_meta="../../data/Test/meta_test.dat", separator_meta = "\\t",
>>>       meta_attr_list=attr_list)

>>> event_list = [("Event A", 20, 60), ("Event B", 120, 180), ("Event C", 400, 500)]

>>> test_network_list, test_df_list = event_time_networks(test_df, events=event_list)
>>> print(test_df_list[0])
     Time i  j TimeGroup
1    40  1  2   Event A
2    40  1  3   Event A
3    40  2  3   Event A
4    60  4  6   Event A
5    60  4  7   Event A
6    60  6  7   Event A
>>> print(test_network_list[0].nodes)
[1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7]
>>> print(test_network_list[0].edges)
[(1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3), (4, 6), (4, 7), (6, 7)]
>>> print(test_df_list[1])
     Time i  j TimeGroup
13   140  7  6   Event B
14   140  4  6   Event B
15   140  7  4   Event B
16   160  7  6   Event B
17   160  4  6   Event B
18   160  7  4   Event B
19   180  7  6   Event B
20   180  4  6   Event B
21   180  7  4   Event B
>>> print(test_network_list[1].nodes)
[4, 6, 7]
>>> print(test_network_list[1].edges)
[(4, 6), (4, 7), (6, 7)]
>>> print(test_df_list[2])
     Time  i   j   TimeGroup
25   420   4   6   Event C
26   420   4   7   Event C
27   420   6   7   Event C
28   440   4   6   Event C
29   440   4   7   Event C
30   440   6   7   Event C
31   440   1   2   Event C
32   440   1   3   Event C
33   440   2   3   Event C
34   460   1   2   Event C
35   460   1   3   Event C
36   460   2   3   Event C
37   460  10  11   Event C
38   460  11  12   Event C
39   460  10  12   Event C
40   500  10  11   Event C
41   500  11  12   Event C
42   500  10  12   Event C
>>> print(test_network_list[2].nodes)
[1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 10, 11, 12]
>>> print(test_network_list[2].edges)
[(1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3), (4, 6), (4, 7), (6, 7), (10, 11), (10, 12), (11, 12)]

See also

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.hopping_time_networks(), sociopatterns.imports.create_network.sliding_time_networks()

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.hopping_time_networks(Data, minutes=1000)

Create multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames

Creating multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames based on the given interval

Parameters

  • Data (Data) – Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset.

  • minutes (int) – The interval time in which the networkx Graphs should be splitted.

Returns

  • network_list (list) – A list of all networkx Graphs for a given interval.

  • df_list (list) – A list of all dataframes for a given interval.

Examples

In this example the full dataframe got splitted in dataframes and networks with timewindows of 40 seconds (2/3 minutes). The Output in this case descripes the network and the dataframe for the first 40 seconds in the original dataframe.

>>> attr_list = ["ID", "Age", "Sex"]
>>> test_df = Data(path_tij="../../data/Test/tij_test.dat", separator_tij="\\t",
>>>                path_meta="../../data/Test/meta_test.dat", separator_meta = "\\t",
>>>                meta_attr_list = attr_list)
>>> test_network_list, test_df_list = hopping_time_networks(test_df, minutes=2/3)
>>> print(test_network_list[0].edges)
[(0, 1), (1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3)]
>>> print(test_network_list[0].nodes)
[0, 1, 2, 3]
>>> for i in test_network_list[0].nodes:
    >>> print(test_network_list[0].nodes[i])
{'Age': 1.0, 'Sex': 'F'}
{'Age': 0.0, 'Sex': nan}
{'Age': nan, 'Sex': 'M'}
{'Age': 0.0, 'Sex': 'F'}
>>> print(test_df_list[0])
   Time  i  j  TimeGroup
0    20  0  1   60.00000
1    40  1  2   60.00000
2    40  1  3   60.00000
3    40  2  3   60.00000

See also

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.create_sliding_time_networks(), sociopatterns.imports.create_network.event_time_networks()

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.replace_str_attr_to_float_2(metadata)
sociopatterns.imports.create_network.sliding_time_networks(Data, slide=1, interval=1000)

Create multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames

Creating multiple Networkx Graphs and DataFrames based on the given interval and a slide.

Parameters

  • Data (Data) – Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset.

  • slide (int) – The time steps in which the intervals should be created.

  • interval (int) – The interval time in which the networkx Graphs should be splitted.

Returns

  • network_list (list) – A list of all networkx Graphs for a given interval.

  • df_list (list) – A list of all dataframes for a given interval.

Examples

>>> attr_list = ["ID", "Age", "Sex"]
>>> test_df = Data(path_tij="../../data/Test/tij_test.dat", separator_tij="\\t",
>>>                path_meta="../../data/Test/meta_test.dat", separator_meta = "\\t",
>>>                meta_attr_list=attr_list)
>>> test_network_list, test_df_list = sliding_time_networks(test_df, slide=1/3, interval=2/3)
>>> print(test_df_list[0])
Time  i  j  TimeGroup
0    20  0  1          0
1    40  1  2          0
3    40  1  3          0
5    40  2  3          0
>>> print(test_network_list[0].nodes)
[0, 1, 2, 3]
>>> print(test_network_list[0].edges)
[(0, 1), (1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3)]
>>> print(test_df_list[1])
Time  i  j  TimeGroup
2     40  1  2          1
4     40  1  3          1
6     40  2  3          1
7     60  4  6          1
9     60  4  7          1
11    60  6  7          1
>>> print(test_network_list[1].nodes)
[1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7]
>>> print(test_network_list[1].edges)
[(1, 2), (1, 3), (2, 3), (4, 6), (4, 7), (6, 7)]

See also

sociopatterns.imports.create_network.hopping_time_networks(), sociopatterns.imports.create_network.event_time_networks()

sociopatterns.imports.import_meta_data module¶

sociopatterns.imports.import_meta_data.import_meta(filename, sep, header, engine)

Import of the CSV-files

Imports the CSV-files as a Dataframe and renames the columns for a unified convention.

Parameters

  • filename (str)

  • sep (str)

  • header (int, list of int, default’infer’)

  • engine (str)

Returns

df – A DataFrame with three columns. Named as “Time”, “i”, “j”.

Return type

DataFrame

Notes

References

  • header (int, list of int, default’infer’)

sociopatterns.imports.load_all_data module¶

class sociopatterns.imports.load_all_data.Data(data_set_name=None, path_tij=None, separator_tij=None, path_meta=None, separator_meta=None, meta_attr_list=None, header=None)

Bases: object

replace_str_attr_to_float()

Replace string attribute values

Replaces string attributes into float attributes for the null model functions.

selfData

Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset.

selfData

Data Object that contains Tij- and Metadata for a dataset. Metadata string attribute values are changed into float values.

As you can see in this example every non-numerical or NaN value gets replaced into a float value. In this case “F” turns into 0.0 and “M” turns into 1.0.

#>>> attr_list = [“ID”, “Age”, “Sex”] #>>> test_df = Data(path_tij=”../../data/Test/tij_test.dat”, separator_tij=” “, #>>> path_meta=”../../data/Test/meta_test.dat”, separator_meta=” “, #>>> meta_attr_list=attr_list) #>>> print(test_df.metadata)

ID Age Sex

Index

0 0 1.00000 F 1 1 0.00000 NaN 2 2 nan M 3 3 0.00000 F 4 4 nan M 5 6 1.00000 F 6 7 1.00000 NaN 7 10 2.00000 F 8 11 2.00000 M 9 12 2.00000 F #>>> test_df.replace_str_attr_to_float() #>>> print(test_df.metadata)

ID Age Sex

Index

0 0 1.00000 0.00000 1 1 0.00000 NaN 2 2 NaN 1.00000 3 3 0.00000 0.00000 4 4 NaN 1.00000 5 6 1.00000 0.00000 6 7 1.00000 NaN 7 10 2.00000 0.00000 8 11 2.00000 1.00000 9 12 2.00000 0.00000

Load Example Data Sets

Loads the given Example Data Sets from the Data folder.

data_set_name (str)

Returns

  • df_tij (DataFrame) – A DataFrame with three columns. Named as “Time”, “Pers1”, Pers2”.

  • df_meta (DataFrame) – A DataFrame with the given Metadata.
